title: 114_s998
content: The Act titled "American Manufacturing Competitiveness Act of 2015" is referenced in Section 1. Section 2 highlights the Congress's recognition of the need for a Miscellaneous Tariff Bill. The American Manufacturing Competitiveness Act of 2015 aims to update the Harmonized Tariff Schedule every 3 years to eliminate artificial distortions in the economy caused by duties on goods with insufficient domestic availability. Regular updates will enhance US manufacturing competitiveness globally. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule is updated to suspend or reduce duties on goods to promote US manufacturing competitiveness. Congress should consider a miscellaneous tariff bill within 180 days after reports on proposed duty suspensions and reductions are issued. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule is updated to suspend or reduce duties on goods to promote US manufacturing competitiveness. Congress should consider a miscellaneous tariff bill within 180 days after reports on proposed duty suspensions and reductions are issued. SEC. 3 outlines the process for consideration of duty suspensions and reductions. The purpose of this section is to establish a process for submitting and considering proposed duty suspensions and reductions. The appropriate congressional committees are required to establish a process by October 15, 2015, and October 15, 2018, for the inclusion of duty suspensions and reductions in a miscellaneous tariff bill. The Commission must publish a notice requesting the public to submit proposed duty suspensions and reductions, along with disclosure forms. This process must be completed within a 60-day period, with submissions sent to Congress promptly after. The Commission must submit proposed duty suspensions and reductions to Congress within 15 days after the 60-day period, and publish them on a publicly available website. The Commission must submit reports to Congress within 90 days of proposing duty suspensions and reductions, detailing information on each proposed duty suspension or reduction, including a determination on domestic production impact. The Commission must submit reports to Congress within 90 days of proposing duty suspensions and reductions, detailing information on each proposed duty suspension or reduction, including domestic production impact, technical changes, tariff revenue implications, and availability to importers. The Commission will establish procedures for duty suspension compliance and operate under its authorities as per the Tariff Act of 1930. The Department of Commerce, in collaboration with relevant agencies, will submit a report within 90 days of proposed duty suspensions and reductions. The Department of Commerce, along with other Federal agencies, will submit a report to congressional committees on proposed duty suspensions and reductions. The report will include information on domestic production, objections from domestic producers, and any necessary technical changes to article descriptions for importation. Proposed duty suspensions or reductions by Members of Congress will not receive preferential treatment. The treatment of proposed duty suspensions or reductions submitted by the public will not be more favorable than those submitted by Members of Congress. SEC. 4. REPORT ON EFFECTS OF DUTY SUSPENSIONS AND REDUCTIONS ON UNITED STATES ECONOMY. The Commission is required to submit a report on the effects of temporary duty suspensions and reductions on the US economy, including an assessment of the economic impact on producers, purchasers, and consumers. The report should also include recommendations for domestic industries that could benefit from permanent duty suspensions or reductions. The report required by this section will focus on inequities created by tariff inversions and may include a classified annex. SEC. 5. JUDICIAL REVIEW PRECLUDED. The exercise of functions under this Act shall not be subject to judicial review. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and Senate. The term "Commission" refers to the United States International Trade Commission. The term "Commission disclosure form" is a document submitted to the Commission regarding proposed duty suspensions or reductions. The term "duty suspension or reduction" refers to an amendment in the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States that extends temporary duty relief on specific articles. A "domestic producer" is defined as a person producing or about to produce a similar article in the United States. The duty suspension or reduction allows temporary relief on specific articles under the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States, with a maximum revenue loss of $500,000. A miscellaneous tariff bill contains duty suspensions and reductions with a maximum revenue loss of $500,000 in a calendar year. The duty relief is available to any person importing the article subject to the suspension or reduction. A Member of Congress refers to a Senator, Representative, Delegate, or Resident Commissioner. To qualify for duty suspensions and reductions, imports must meet requirements outlined in section 3 and not be objected to by a Member of Congress or domestic producer. The Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States may be amended by appropriate congressional committees, the Commission, or the Department of Commerce to correct errors in the text or administration.
